caption.p: Common adverse reactions to antiretroviral and antitubercular drugs

tr.td: Lzd, Cs, H, Sm, Km, Am, Eto/Pto, E

● Avoid use of D4T, ddI, and ddC in combination with Cs or Lzd because of increased peripheral neuropathy ● If these agents must be used and peripheral neuropathy develops, replace the ART with a less neurotoxic agent
Cs, H, Eto/Pto, Ofx, Lfx, Mfx, Lzd

● Efv has a high rate of adverse CNS drug reactions (confusion, impaired concentration, depersonalization, abnormal dreams, insomnia, and dizziness) in the first 2–3 weeks, which typically resolve on their own ● If these effects do not resolve on their own, consider substitution of the agent
Cs, Tzd, Ofx, Lfx, Mfx, H, Eto/Pto
● Severe depression can be seen in 2.4% of patients receiving Efv ● Consider substituting for Efv if severe depression develops

● Rule out more serious causes of headache, such as bacterial meningitis, cryptococcal meningitis, CNS toxoplasmosis ● Use of analgesics (ibuprofen, paracetamol) and good hydration may help. ● Headache secondary to Azt, Efv, and Cs is usually self-limited
Eto/Pto, PAS, H, E, Z, Bdq

● Nausea and vomiting are common adverse drug reactions and can be managed ● Persistent vomiting and abdominal pain may be a result of developing lactic acidosis and/or hepatitis secondary to medications
All ART treatments have been associated with abdominal pain
● Abdominal pain is a common adverse drug reaction and often benign ● Abdominal pain may be an early symptom of severe adverse drug reactions, such as pancreatitis, hepatitis, or lactic acidosis

● Avoid use of these agents together ● If an agent causes pancreatitis, suspend it permanently and do not use any pancreatitis-producing ART (D4T, ddI, or ddC) in future. ● Also consider gallstones or alcohol as a potential cause of pancreatitis
All protease inhibitors, ddI (buffered formula), Rgv
● Diarrhea is a common adverse drug reaction ● Also consider opportunistic infections as a cause of diarrhea, or Clostridium difficile (a cause of pseudomembranous colitis)
Nvp, Efv, all PIs, all NsRTIs, all integrase inhibitors, maraviroc
H, R, E, Z, PAS, Eto/Pto, Ofx, Lfx, Mfx, Bdq
● Also consider Tmp-Smx as a cause of hepatotoxicity if the patient is receiving this medication ● Also rule out viral etiologies, such as cause of hepatitis (hepatitis A, B, C, and CMV)
H, R, Z, PAS, Am, Km, Ofx, Lfx, Mfx, Amx-Clv, T

● Do not rechallenge with Abc (can result in life-threatening anaphylaxis) ● Do not rechallenge with an agent that causes Stevens–Johnson syndrome ● Also consider Tmp-Smx as a cause of skin rash if the patient is receiving this medication ● T is contraindicated in HIV because of life-threatening rash
● If an agent causes lactic acidosis, replace it with an agent less likely to cause lactic acidosis

● TDF may cause renal injury with features characteristic of Fanconi syndrome, hypophosphatemia, hypouricemia, proteinuria, normoglycemic glycosuria, and in some cases acute renal failure ● Use TDF with caution in patients receiving aminoglycosides or Cm and Lfx ● Mfx should be preferred when ART contains TDF ● Frequent creatinine and electrolyte monitoring every 1 to 3 weeks is recommended

● No overlapping toxicities regarding nephrolithiasis have been documented between ART and anti-TB medications ● Adequate hydration prevents nephrolithiasis in patients taking Idv ● If nephrolithiasis develops while on Idv, substitute with another PI if possible

● Diarrhea and/or vomiting can contribute to electrolyte disturbances ● Even without concurrent use of TDF, HIV-infected patients have increased risk of both renal toxicity and electrolyte disturbances secondary to aminoglycosides and Cm

● Monitor blood counts regularly ● Replace Azt if bone-marrow suppression develops ● Consider suspension of Lzd ● Also consider Tmp-Smx as a cause if the patient is receiving this medication ● Consider adding folinic acid supplements, especially if receiving Tmp-Smx
● Suspend agent responsible for optic neuritis permanently ● Replace with an agent that does not cause optic neuritis
● No overlapping toxicities regarding hyperlipidemia have been documented between ART and anti-TB medications
● No overlapping toxicities regarding lipodystrophy have been documented between ART and anti-TB medications
● PIs tend to cause insulin resistance and hyperglycemia ● Eto/Pto tend to make insulin control in diabetics more difficult and can result in hypoglycemia and poor glucose regulation

● There is potential for overlying toxicity, but evidence is mixed ● Several studies show subclinical hypothyroidism associated with ART, particularly d4T ● PAS and Eto/Pto, especially in combination, can commonly cause hypothyroidism

● Clinical correlation to rule out offending drug ● Monitoring with creatine phosphokinase ● Thorough clinical evaluation to rule out HIV-associated myopathy ● Muscle biopsy can be performed ● Azt-associated mitochondrial myopathy
● Close monitoring to be done by ECG ● Mfx is more commonly associated with QT prolongation ● Lfx preferred over Mfx
